meanings.definition: To make (attitudes or behavior) part of one's nature by learning or unconscious assimilation.
meanings.sent1: She was internalising the importance of kindness through her daily interactions.
meanings.sent2: Children often start internalising social norms from a young age.
meanings.sent3: The puppy seemed to be internalising the concept of fetch, but kept bringing back sticks instead of the ball.
meanings.sent4: As the sun set, the colors of the sky were internalising into a beautiful painting.
meanings.sent5: The teacher used colorful visuals to help students internalise the new vocabulary words.

meanings.definition: To incorporate (external values or beliefs) into one's own thinking or behavior.
meanings.sent1: He was internalising the advice from his mentor on how to approach challenges.
meanings.sent2: Many people struggle with internalising societal expectations while staying true to themselves.
meanings.sent3: The robot was internalising the instructions it received, causing it to perform unexpected actions.
meanings.sent4: The melody of the song was internalising into her mind, making it hard to forget.
meanings.sent5: The artist was internalising different art styles to create a unique masterpiece.
